summary: John F. Rittenhouse was an individual associated with the CIA's Overseas Branch (OPC). In late 1950, there were plans to change his status from an OPC Staff Employee to an OPC Staff Agent and assign him to Mexico City as a GS-13 Intelligence Officer under State Department deep cover. Security concurrence was sought and granted for this assignment. However, his security clearance was later canceled, and he was reclassified as a semi-covert employee integrated into a department. Later, he is mentioned in a document regarding security deletions and revisions to E. Howard Hunt's manuscript, 'Undercover: Memoirs of an American Agent.'
significance: While the documents detail Rittenhouse's CIA activities and a proposed assignment to Mexico City, his direct significance to the JFK assassination context is not explicitly stated in these documents. The connection to E. Howard Hunt, who was later implicated in Watergate and had connections to anti-Castro activities, might warrant further investigation, but the provided documents do not establish a direct link to the assassination.
